protocol.title: Differentiation of iPSC into Microglia-Like Cells (iMGL)
protocol.title_html: Differentiation of iPSC into Microglia-Like Cells (iMGL)

source.description: Thaw and culture iPSC line per the following protocol:

source.title: iPSC Cell Culture – Maintenance and Expansion

authors.name: Jacob Marsh
authors.affiliation: Washington University in Saint Louis - WUSTL (MO)

source.description: {"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"95clo","text":"This protocol is about Maintenance and Expansion of induced pluripotent stem cells.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]}
Once iPSCs are 70-80% confluent in 2-3 wells of a 6-well tissue culture plate, passage and plate the iPSCs as aggregates

source.body: Aggregates should be approximately 100-200µm in diameter

source.description:
Coat a 6-well tissue culture plate with Matrigel for a least
prior to passaging cells

source.body: A single 6-well tissue culture plate will yield approximately 1-1.5 million HPCs

source.description:
Set the following media out to warm to
:
  • Dispase
  • DMEM/F12
  • PBS
  • mTesR1

After plate has been coated for
and media has warmed to
, proceed to passage aggregates as described below:
Aspirate media from well.

Wash cells with
per well
Aspirate PBS from well.

Add Dispase to cells
.

Incubate at
for between
and
.

source.body: Edges of iPSC clusters should begin to lift off the Matrigel coated plate
Cells will not completely dissociate from Matrigel coated plate. The majority of cells will remain attached after the incubation.

source.description: Aspirate the Dispase from the wells.

Gently wash cells 2-3 times with
per well, aspirating after each wash.

source.body: The major goal of this step is to remove the Dispase without substantially disturbing the cells.

source.description:
Add
to each well.
Using the StemProEZPassage Disposable Stem Cell Passaging Tool, cut the iPSCs into aggregates that are approximately 100-200µm in diameter.

source.body: To accomplish this, the StemPro EZPassage Disposable Stem Cell Passaging Tool should be rolled throughout the entirety of the well horizontally (twice) and vertically (twice). This will result in the appropriate sized aggregates for plating.

source.description: Transfer the detached aggregates with a serological pipette into a 15 ml conical tube.

source.body: Check tissue culture plate under microscope to ensure that the majority of aggregates have been transferred from the plate.
If aggregates still remain, wash well with 2mL of DMEM/F12 and transfer to 15mL conical tube

source.description:
Centrifuge 15 ml conical tubes containing cell aggregates at 750 rpm for
.
Aspirate supernatant from cell pellet.
Resuspend pellet gently in

source.body: Obtaining a uniform suspension of aggregates approximately 100-200µm in diameter is optimal. The StemPro EZPassage Disposable Stem Cell Passaging Tool should be used to ensure these aggregate sizes.
It is essential that pellet is resuspended by pipetting only one time, this ensures a larger degree of cell survival – as cells are incredibly delicate at this stage.

source.description: Perform triplicate aggregate counts to determine the average number of cell aggregates.

Pipette
into three individual wells of a 96-well flat bottom tissue culture plate.

Pipette
to each well.
Manually count the number of aggregates in each well.

source.body: Do not count aggregates smaller than 100µm

source.description: Calculate the average number of aggregates per well.

source.body: Add the number of aggregates per well and then divide by 3 to find the average number of aggregates per well

source.description: Next calculate the Concentration of Aggregates or Aggregates/uL.

source.body: Take the average number of aggregates per well and divide by 5 (the dilution factor) to obtain the number of aggregates per microliter.

source.description: Determine the number of aggregates to plate in a 6-well tissue culture plate.

source.body: It is recommended plating 130-160 aggregates per well (optimal for control iPSC lines). This density typically results in 20-38 colonies per well after 24 hours of incubation.
The number of aggregates plated can be adjusted depending on how particular iPSC lines behave.
Plating more aggregates at this stage does not result in more HPCs obtained at the end of the protocol.

source.description:
Calculating the plating volume of the cell aggregate mixture is accomplished by dividing the number of aggregates to plate by the concentration of the cell aggregates. For example:
1. Plate 130 aggregates per well
2. Concentration of Cell Aggregates =3 Aggregates/µL
3. 130 Aggregates per Well / 3 Aggregates per µL= Plate ~43µL of Aggregate Mixture per Well

After calculating the number of aggregates to plate per well, aspirate Matrigel from previously coated 6-well plate(s) (refer to Step 2), and add
containing 2.5µM Rock Inhibitor to each well.
Gently mix the cell aggregate mixture by inverting 15mL conical tube.

source.body: Do not vortex or pipette mixture.

source.description: Add the previously calculated volume of aggregate suspension to each well in the 6-well plate.

Place the plate containing mTesR1 and aggregate suspension in incubator at
for
.

source.body: Prior to placing plate in incubator, perform a “t” shaped motion with the plate to ensure that aggregates are distributed evenly throughout the wells.

source.description: After 24 hours, carefully aspirate mTesR1 containing 2.5µM Rock Inhibitor from each well.

Gently wash cells with
per well.
Aspirate PBS.

Add
to each well.
Visualize plate under microscope and manually count the number of adhered aggregates per well.

source.body: Aim for at least 20 adhered aggregates per well of a 6-well tissue culture plate
Do not proceed further if < 20 aggregates or > 40 aggregates have adhered to 6-well tissue culture plate as differentiation will be compromised

source.body: Medium B can be prepped and stored for a maximum of three days

source.body: At this point, floating cells can often be seen in culture and they will continue to increase in number for the remainder of the protocol.

source.body: As the number of floating cells in the culture increases, it is imperative that media changes are done slowly and gently to avoid removing a large number of the floating cells.

source.description: Harvesting Cells for FACS Sorting:

source.title: iPSCs Induction into Hematopoietic Stem Cells

source.description:
Floating and adherent cells should be harvested for FACS sorting on the twelfth day of culture for presence of the following cellular markers:
1) CD43
2) CD34
3) CD45

source.title: iPSCs Induction into Hematopoietic Stem Cells

source.description: Begin harvesting floating cells using a serological pipette or 1mL micropipette, vigorously pipette media and cells up and down approximately 2-3 times in the well to break up floating cell aggregates.

source.title: iPSCs Induction into Hematopoietic Stem Cells

source.description: Transfer floating cells and media to appropriately sized conical tube.

source.title: of sterile FACS Buffer (PBS and 2% FBS)
FACS Sorting CD43+ CD34+ CD45+ Cells

source.description:
To stain cells for FACS sorting, add the following antibodies to the filtered cell suspension (cells and FACS Buffer) in the noted concentrations:
  • CD34-FITC (1:200)
  • CD43-APC (1:200)
  • CD45 – Alexa Fluor700 (1:200) (optional)
  • CD41-PE (1:200) (optional)

source.title: FACS Sorting CD43+ CD34+ CD45+ Cells

in the dark for

source.title: FACS Sorting CD43+ CD34+ CD45+ Cells

source.description: Sort the CD34+ and CD43+cell population using a Becton Dickinson FACSAria II.

source.body: Sorting has to be performed in sterile conditions.
In order to obtain high quality HPCs, it is suggested to sort only the CD34+ and CD43+ double positive cell population, discarding the single or double negative cells.

source.description:
Using previously sorted cryopreserved cells (Freezing Down Sorted Hematopoietic Stem Cells Section), place frozen vial of cells in
for quick thaw.

source.body: Thaw should take less than one minute, remove cells from water bath prior to complete thaw.

source.description:
iMGL Diff Complete Medium Recipe:
ABCDE
1VendorCetalog #Dilution
2iMGL Diff Base Medium
3IL-34 (100 ng/ml)Peprotech200-341:5000
4TGFb-1 (50 ng/ml)Peprotech100-211:2000
5M-CSF (25 ng/ml)Peprotech300-251:4000

ABCDE
1VendorCetalog #Dilution
2iMGL Diff Base Medium
3IL-34 (100 ng/ml)Peprotech200-341:5000
4TGFb-1 (50 ng/ml)Peprotech100-211:2000
5M-CSF (25 ng/ml)Peprotech300-251:4000

source.body: iMGL Diff Base Medium can be kept in storage at 4°C for approximately one month. It is important to make fresh iMGL Diff Complete Medium (addition of fresh cytokines to the base medium) every time you need to feed the culture

source.body: iMGL Diff Base Medium can be kept in storage at 4°C for approximately one month. It is important to make fresh iMGL Diff Complete Medium (addition of fresh cytokines to the base medium) every time you need to feed the culture

source.title: Differentiation of Hematopoietic Stem Cells into iMGLs

source.description: Day 28 - Cells should have reached maturity by this step.

source.body: Continue feeding cells with iMGL Maturation Media. Mature Microglia-Like Cells can be used for approximately 2-3 weeks.
Mature iMGLs can be also be detached with Accutase ( at ) and replated on plastic or glass culture ware that has been pre-coated with Matrigel.

description: This protocol outlines the derivation of Hematopoietic Progenitor Cells and differentiation of iMGLs using iPSC cultures. This protocol is modified the following papers.
